job_title: Director of Operations in Mount Royal, NJ
pros: I have worked for Autism Speaks for over 20 years and have experienced many changes throughout my tenure. I am proud to say that I am an employee of Autism Speaks. I have seen the organization make great strides over the years to improve the culture for employees. The leadership today cares about the well being of their staff and they are invested in their futures. They provide an excellent benefits package, will do what they can to support employees while they are dealing with personal challenges, and will offer guidance when needed. The staff are very dedicated to the mission to help support the autism community. Autism Speaks listens to feedback from the community and continues to implement positive changes in response to that feedback. The organization truly cares about their employees, every autistic individual and their families, as well as professionals that support the community.
cons: It's unfortunate that decisions made by previous leadership teams still impact the reputation of Autism Speaks today. Autism Speaks continues to evolve and works daily to support all autistic individuals in any way that they need.

review_title: High Level Work with Passionate People
pros: Expectations at Autism Speaks are high; we have a big mission and a big responsibility to the community and the organization takes this very seriously. I enjoy working in this type of environment. It would be a huge challenge if those high expectations were not supported by collaborative, kind co-workers. There may be days when we do not see eye to eye on certain issues or approaches, but at the end of each day we treat one another with kindness and respect. You come to Autism Speaks to push yourself to perform at your absolute best as a professional and also share energy with your coworkers to support their efforts - this is how we achieve our mission.
cons: I think the public sees us as this huge organization with all kinds of depth on our organizational chart. The truth in many cases is we achieve a ton because individuals give 150% to their work. The balance between being the go-to place for the autism community and keeping our workloads manageable is delicate. Anyone joining our organization will need to be flexible and adaptable to the brisk pace and demands of this work.

review_title: Hangover effect of bad decisions during COVID
pros: Remote work environment for majority of employees Field management is great and knows what needs to happen but is constantly pressured to overperfom despite organizational challenges that impact ability to do so
cons: NYC minded organization that focuses on an agenda that isn’t always reflected in other communities. Working here as a conservative leaning employee was difficult. They spend a lot of time worried about DEI initiatives but not diversity of perspective. The organization isn’t always accepted in the autism community and staff take a lot of hate from community members, both online and in person. The organization doesn’t defend themselves against these attacks and refuses to apologize for misgivings of the past. Consistently giving employees more responsibility and unfairly promoting some and underpaying others. There has a been a huge exodus of employees since 2020 but the expectation on those remaining is to do more with less. HR is overly focused on organizational preservation, to the detriment of managers who can’t easily deal with bad performance, get told they are the problem and receive one-sided feedback. They are laser focused on getting good scores on best places to work but not actually on being a best place to work.

review_title: Proud to work for an organization that listens to autistic voices

pros: I have worked for Autism Speaks going on four years now and I have to say the organization is doing a great job in building up the vision. review_title: Autism Speaks needs a fresh start with a new leadership team
pros:
-Wonderful volunteers and families who are touched by autism
-Great coworkers who cared about the autism community
cons:
-CEO and Leadership team do not know how to lead and are SLOW to respond to changes. They take months to develop strategies that don't work because they are so afraid to make the wrong decisions or face additional criticism from the public. They need to understand that they will never make everyone happy and that you have to break eggs to bake a cake. In the meantime opportunities are lost and the Leadership team does not take accountability for dropping the ball.
-HR has been a revolving door and this is another area where the senior leadership team moves very slowly.  Many people complained about someone's abusive management style and it still took over a year to dismiss that person. 
-Autism Speaks stopped doing work that benefits families and those with autism and then wonder why their fundraising from their community has moved on to other causes. They blame local staff members across the country, but the donors see that Autism Speaks is not showing up in their community.
-Review system is bogus. Goals aren't real and people get "good" (that's the best anyone gets) reviews only to get laid off and told they weren't doing a good job 3 weeks later. The whole system is a huge waste of time, but HR is very proud of the system they implemented.
-Staff members with talent left months ago. Those employees can see through management's gas lighting, excuses, and abuse.

pros: Autism Speaks has incredible history in the community, and truly made "autism" a household conversation around the world. What Autism Speaks has done for awareness, research, treatment and advocacy worldwide is outstanding. Being a part of that mission, as well as having the opportunity to build relationships in the local community, is incredibly rewarding.
cons: There are unfortunately many concerns I have as an employee. There is a great lack of communication from top NYC leadership down to the field, and this could come from too many (highly compensated) executive hands in the cookie jar. Field staff, who have some of the toughest responsibilities (i.e. fundraising for the mission of the organization) do not receive competitive pay and benefits for the workload and time required. Benefits are basic at best and pay is under industry standard. Many staff are here because they are committed to the cause, but that passion doesn't pay the bills at the end of the day. There is quite a disconnect between organizational leadership and the field staff, often leaving them feeling unsupported, frustrated, and just plain burnt out. There is also little to no room for growth.

pros: They are good at raising awareness of ASD.

pros: Amazing coworkers and volunteer leaders

pros:
I enjoy the idea of working to help others. This job did allow me the opportunity to assist those  who were on the spectrum.  
Salaries are competitive with the market and the health benefits are nice.
cons:
Too much politics.  The upper managers, led by the new president Liz Feld, rule by fear of expulsion. This wasn't always the atmosphere.  The people at the top used to care about the employees and the mission.  Now they are only focused on the money, which is frequently used for expensive trips and high salaries. (Check their public tax documents, You will see what I mean.)
      There is also a contentious environment because they have no institutional memory.  Any major accomplishments you have done in the past are disregarded and people are frequently replaced just so the new management can have their friends on staff.  
      Also, some of the company practices are "questionable" in nature and those that speak up about these matters are swiftly terminated.

pros: Nobody seems to care when nothing gets done or goes badly. Employees can bond over how disorganized and discombobulated the place is.
cons: There is no reality of life-work balance. you're expected to work nights and weekends and then volunteer until you fall apart or quit, just like every one does. there's a huge turnover, EVEN at the executive level, which creates a lot of insecurity and instability. Everyone is walking in egg shells all the time. At every level. Seems like the top execs are changing directions all the time and the reflects down a lot. I've had a few issues with people 2 or 3 people above me just because they'd yell like children or abuse their positions. No one cares about the regular people. There's NO interest in them being happy at work. Most of the people they hire are connected to someone high up, so that creates a nepotism regulated place, with no real talent. I've seen things that would curl people's eyelashes and it's common practice. Plus, people get fired every week, in the just one office I am.

review_title: Hear it's better there now, but that's not saying much
job_title: Anonymous Employee in New York, NY
pros: Compensation and benefits were pretty good for a non-profit, and, despite some of the organization's more controversial attitudes and policies over the years, they really do make a significant and positive difference in the lives of many families who live with autism. The times that you felt you were actually helping people (and doing it alongside dedicated and good people outside of management who worked there) sometimes helped balance out the more negative aspects of working there.
cons: Evidently most of the senior management structure there has changed significantly over the past year or two, but I can't imagine that they're not still being hampered by the incompetence of the top-level management there for the years I was there. The number of good, hard-working people they drove out or fired because they wouldn't tow the misguided organizational priorities or couldn't meet their unreasonable goals was mind-boggling. The entire culture there became utterly toxic, and no one respected the president or the people around her. Their fundraising numbers were well down, and they managed to anger or push away most of the grassroots in favor of more and more DC political consultants who had no idea what the autism community really wanted. Rather than actually seek to address the internal morale problems though, they simply attempted to purge anyone out who hadn't drunk the kool-aid.

review_title: Just when you though AS hit bottom, it gets worse
pros: Working with the families impacted by Autism and the few coworkers left who have children on the spectrum.
cons: It's difficult to know where to start.  There is a lot of heart in some staff but the top is all about themselves and hiring their unqualified friends for high positions.    Leadership is from the for-profit world and they do not understand the mission or families they represent.   Staff with a connection to Autism are not valued.   The last 3 years have shown the organizations true colors. They pushed out or fired all leadership with a connection to Autism and seem to be working their way down the levels to rid the organization of anyone who cares about the cause.   It's a very unpleasant atmosphere where they bully anyone that does not agree with the bad decisions.

pros: Working on a mission of deep importance to society, helping families and those affected by autism.
cons: A dysfunctional and unsettling environment since June 2012.  Approximately 90% of senior staff has left in the past 14 months, and roughly 30% of staff nationally has left during this time.  This is directly correlated  with the dubious leadership/direction the new CEO has taken the organization in.  There have been rolling layoffs for 14 months, many of which are strategically questionable.  New senior staff is being hired that does not have the experience, qualifications, or knowledge for the jobs they are brought on to do.  The Board appears to be looking the other way, despite these alarming trends.  A pervasive atmosphere of fear is predicated by top leadership, and they have a concerning lack of understanding of departmental missions and profession operations.  Work/life balance is all but impossible as all staff (even mid and low-level) are expected to be on-call 24/7 for all things - including unimportant minutiae - regardless if they have the commensurate pay to warrant these types of demands on personal time.

review_title: Organization is on the way up

pros: A lot of changes and potential with a new level of focus, heading in a proactive direction. Much time will be spent leveling out, getting organized and making needed investments in infrastructure and raising standards. High hopes to see the org on a list of competitive places to work thereafter. The mission is meaningful to millions.
cons:
Being flexible to changing priorities is a must at most non-profit foundations. But right now at this org it's the only way to exist. Change, even for the better, is not easy and can be difficult for some to negotiate. 
A culture of excuses is a hard habit to break after so long. Focus on accountability at all levels and challenge employees to raise standards.

pros: The benefits are pretty nice, especially for a nonprofit. Some of the managers are pretty great, but are quickly beaten down.  If you're outside of the New York office, things are fairly pleasant.
cons: Tiny merit increases that don't keep up with cost of living. Almost no promotion from within, except within the same small pool.  Incredibly high workloads with little to no support. Unrealistic goals that employees have no hand in setting. You'll be required to do a ton of work, then only get evaluated on how much money you bring in.  Feedback from the rank-and-file is considered hostile. There is no realistic view of numbers - it doesn't matter what market you're in or how well (or poorly) you've performed in the past, you need to increase revenue by X%.  The Human Resources department only knows New York and New Jersey labor law, so if you're outside of those states, you'll need to quote the law to get what you're entitled to.

pros: Close to transportation... Good location, that's it! Though food options in the area are not great. The medical benefits are not that bad actually.
cons:
It's a big mess. Don't do it. Everyone is confused, overpaid, exhausted, under-pressure (or threatened) and there's no real organization. Ask anyone.
Besides that, no knows anyone in the office, people barely talk to each other, not even in the kitchen, there's no real "team" or "culture", even when you try hard. Everyone is in their own little hell. Lots of gossiping. Lots of internal struggles over donors' dollars and responsibilities. Lots of shoving work around. No one is happy and it shows.

review_title: The New President that Changed Everything
pros: At one time there was great comradery amongst employees, who worked together to support an under-served community.
cons: I worked for Autism Speaks for many years. The job could be at times challenging but the work for the most part was rewarding. The goodwill that was built up over the years completely dissolved when Autism Speaks' new president took office in 2012. What was once a warm and welcoming environment that served the autism community almost immediately turned into an atmosphere of hostility and bullying led by its new president. Favoritism reigned and dedicated, long term employees were either forced out or fired.

review_title: The Patients are Running the Asylum
pros: The mission and the families that look to AS for hope
cons: Wasteful spending on consultants and advocacy instead of desperately needed research and services. I believe the CEO is using AS as a breeding ground to try and reignite her former "fiasco" of an attempt at a political career

pros: Acceptance health Benefits, good PTO and sick time accrual rate.
cons: Very little opportunities for growth. Autism Speak does not like to hire from within, instead they seek to fill positions from outside the organization. The salaries are also extremely low, compared to larger nonprofits. The CEO and many other senior leadership staff make obscene amounts of money, reflected in company's 990 Form. However, fundraising staff, who are a major part of the organization, are some of the most undercompensated.

review_title: Fundamentally Flawed Company Cannot Get Out of Its Own Way
pros:
- The day-to-day interactions with families, and individuals with autism were generally positive and rewarding.
- Extraordinary volunteers make the organization shine in some communities.
- Advocating on behalf of a well-known brand was both a Pro and a Con.
- No micromanaging  for the bulk of my time there.
- Some of the internal systems were sophisticated (Payroll, Social Media, Travel reimbursement).
- I learned a lot from my bosses, who were both good people.
- In theory, the mission is solid.
cons:
- My boss had five different bosses over the course of three years.  That really says it all.
- National priorities were constantly changing, processes and systems were rotating in and out on a monthly basis, chapter priorities were pushed aside, and we never really knew if we achieved anything. 
- There was a total, 100% disconnect between the NY HQ and the chapters/major market staff. There were NY/NJ staff who tried to make connections, sure; but I have never worked at a national company so thoroughly confused by its own infrastructure. It was a total mess, and in four years it never got better. 
- HR, IT, Web Services, Facilities - all the departments you expect to be rock solid at a national organization of this age and size, were actually under-funded, under-staffed, and not  thoroughly professional. The HR department was especially disappointing. Lots of turnover there, and terrible, rushed communication. 
- The end-user services that Autism Speaks touts so highly (Family Services, Advocacy, and Science) are not delivered evenly across the country. Mostly East Coast and California benefit. Western and southern states get very little. It is incredibly hard to raise money in an area that isn't receiving any tangible services. 
- The compensation sounds great when you are taking a job at Autism Speaks. But then  you find yourself working so many nights and weekends and realize why the salary was so good. If they had had to pay us an hourly rate, they'd be broke.  I worked hard for the volunteers and families in my region, but I missed a lot of weekends and evenings with my own family.

pros: There is a ground staff that is consistently empowering and encouraging each other that tries to balance out the negative aspects of this organization.
cons:
Time to say what most of the reviewers below are too hesitant to say:

This organization is in the process of a very heartbreaking disintegration stemming from the misdirection of the president and her senior suite. The breakdown internally has separated the organization from the well-respected and visible key leaders of the national autism community and has dismantled the relationships the charity so closely depends on from ground fundraisers and advocates. The CoFounders will have some serious apologies to make if they don't recognize these issues soon; or if not, they must be totally willing to surrender their own well-earned reputation along with the organization completely. 

For two years now there has been a widening hole in the bucket with the organization losing so much talent, that it's impossible to justify by Feld. She constantly points, implies and blames all lack of progress to 'deeply rooted' disorganization and lack of skill among employees-- it's a slap in the face to the early vision of the organization and makes mission delivery impossible.

The current development strategy in place is theoretical and over-speculated with no real proof that it drives revenue- the leadership literally pulls articles out of the NY Times as evidence of their fundraising ideas. 

Nepotism aside (a significant amount of her executive staff comes from her and her husband's network), the leadership currently hired to be responsible for strategy and development refuses sound advice and declines to employ professionals with the experience to at least give design to poorly conceived fundraising ideas.

The company is also in desperate need for an operations framework. Evaluating success is impossible-- their practices at financial analysis is weak as is the integrity of their data. For Feld's entire tenure the organization has delayed applying for fundraising licenses, applied for extensions to file their 990 with the IRS, and has published their annual reports late. It's Nov 2014-- and the 2013 annual report is only now being produced. 

Finally, if the strategy of the organization was intended to build a lobby and magnify their media presence...then what has happened with the attention from big press?

Feld's issues with communications is completely three dimensional. Externally, she struggles with connecting to the community, and I would describe her prone to incitement and riot. This is more alarming than all her posturing and exhibition-- when 'off stage' she is detached and aloof and simply lacks compassion towards families of the community. In large forums, her stage presence is forced and stern; she stumbles to articulate key facts from the org's own research department, depending on boiler plates and becoming repetitive and insistent. What are we working towards if this is how she communicates?

Internally, she lacks any vertical communication. Department goals are not clear and always changing. Furthermore, Feld models inappropriate behavior towards her suite that has nurtured a hostile work environment with subordinates. The general good humor and energy among middle and junior staff is gone and it seems Feld is in constant ideological battle. Staff are nervous, confused, browbeaten and simply...exiting. 

I'm not sure, given her resume in community politics and children's media, what this woman is searching for-- but the organization would be better off without a rogue Tinman hacking away at everything with his hatchet just to find his heart.

pros: It is satisfying to help families affected by autism.
cons: In the last 2 years the culture of bullying has become pervasive.  Upper management uses tactics of aggressive intimidation in (what appears to be) an attempt to keep staff in line.  Their concern seems be less about the autism community and more about their egos and domination of staff associated with the previous regime.  There have been massive layoffs in recent years that appear to have been done without knowing the consequences of removing successful staff members -  without total knowledge of what their job entailed (creating undue hardship on the new or remaining staff who scramble to learn the previous person's job) People were let go and told that it was due to "budgetary" constraints but at times their exact positions would be replaced the same week.  Many of the released Autism Speaks staff were the parents of children/adults with autism and were undoubtedly assets to the organization.  Some of them were highly respected and revered among the autism community.  Some were dismissed in secret - without publicly announcing their termination. Cronyism is at an all time high - with friends of the CEO being appointed to positions of authority, regardless of their lack of non-profit qualifications.
